Instruction: Modify the molecule CCN(Cc1ccccn1)c1ccc(C=O)o1 by removing a aldehyde.

json_results.delete_strategy: To delete the aldehyde group, we remove the C=O moiety and replace it with a hydrogen atom at the same position on the aromatic ring. This simplifies the structure while preserving the aromaticity and overall integrity of the remaining molecular framework.
json_results.feasibility_analysis: Removing the aldehyde group by replacing it with a hydrogen atom is chemically feasible because it does not disrupt the aromatic character of the ring. This modification would likely be stable under normal conditions, assuming no strong electronic destabilization occurs due to the absence of the electron-withdrawing aldehyde group.

Instruction: Modify the molecule O=C(Nc1ccc(Nc2ccccc2)cc1)c1ccc(O)nc1 by removing a amine.

This simplifies that portion of the molecule while retaining the core aromatic scaffold. Bond connectivity will be maintained by directly linking the para-position to a hydrogen or preserving the substitution pattern if feasible.
json_results.feasibility_analysis: Removing the N-linked phenyl group from the benzene ring is chemically feasible in silico. While such a transformation might require specific chemical reactions in practice (e.g., reductive deamination), it does not violate basic molecular stability rules in theoretical manipulation. The resulting molecule remains chemically valid and retains aromaticity.
